I am a college professor, and I strongly oppose the so-called "Academic Bill of Rights," which I think would simply interfere with and undermine academic freedom. However, it sounds like people in this forum organize a formal debate on topics, and I do not have time to take part in a formal debate right now. I'm sorry about that. 
 
 On the subject you are considering, I know of no fellow professors who support this bill. I am sure there are some, but they are not at my institution. Beyond being unnecessary, the bill would undermine the freedom of universities to determine academic policies and the freedom of faculty members to teach their subjects. The government should not be telling professors what they can and cannot teach or how they should run their classes. The process of hiring and tenure review is the appropriate process by which universities judge the competence and classroom performance of professors. We don't need this law, and it's just a way for extreme right wingers like David Horowitz to try to force their ideology into academic classrooms. 
 
 Professors are trained in their disciplines through many years of graduate study. Professors are judged by peers through the process of academic review and tenure, and many institutions also have procedures for post-tenure review. Most professors teach their discipline effectively and professionally. That some faculty members present radical or very challenging viewpoints in the classroom is a strength of our current academic process, not a weakness. We need professors who push the boundaries of discourse and who challenge currently accepted beliefs. If professors cannot do this, then who can? Academia is where people are supposed to be free to challenge all kinds of orthodoxies and to present new and seemingly radical ideas. If a professor presents a viewpoint with which students disagree, then the students will learn from it. And they can and will take other courses where they are exposed to other viewpoints. One purpose of college is to expose students to a wide range of viewpoints, including viewpoints that challenge the beliefs of the students. 
 
 There may be some students who think that their professors are punishing them for their viewpoints with bad grades. This may happen occasionally, but mostly it does not. Students may not understand why they are getting bad grades, or they may not want to understand why. It's often easier to claim that a professor is giving the student a bad grade because the professor disagrees with the student's opinion than it is to recognize that the student received a bad grade because of poor writing or because of the student's failure to present credible evidence. When it comes to grading, students understandably have strong emotions, and some who get poor grades will try to blame the professors for being biased rather than looking honestly at how hard they actually worked in the class and whether they demonstrated knowledge of the subject or the ability to present a clear argument supported by evidence. 
 
 The professors that I know personally, and this is anecdotal, try very hard to be fair to all students and to use clear grading standards. Most bend over backwards not to judge students on their opinions, but rather to judge how well the students achieve the learning objectives for the class. Students may not always recognize this.
 
 In my own classes, I encourage students to present different viewpoints, and I organize formal debates on questions that emerge from the subject under study. I encourage students to argue positions in the debates with which they disagree, in order to learn the opponents' viewpoints and to see different positions on issues. I had a student a few years ago who was the leading conservative activist on our campus. I, in contrast, am no conservative. Despite our different views on most subjects, this student loved my classes, and I became his mentor. He wrote that I was his favorite professor. He went on to law school, and he is a successful lawyer today. The fact that we disagreed about issues made no difference, because the point of education is not to force conformity of thinking. It's to encourage thinking and the expression of all viewpoints and to teach the use of evidence and scholarship. I have always told my students that I do not care what they believe or what they think. I do care whether they research the positions they take in their papers and debates, whether they assemble and interpret and use evidence effectively, and whether they present their positions clearly and effectively through writing or speaking. 
 
 For the most part, our colleges and universities already do an effective job of teaching students to think, research, reflect, gather evidence, and write. Students have academic freedom and rights already, largely because faculty have academic freedom. We should always seek to improve the education of our students, but we need to do this internally, through faculty development and through better means of assessment, which are currently being put in place in many institutions. We do not need, and we should reject, efforts to pass laws that undermine academic freedom in the name of enhancing it.

 Professor Sues College for Partisan Firing
 
 By Katrina Irwin--WROC-TV--11/01/04 
 A former professor at Monroe Community College says he was fired because he showed his support for President Bush. Dr. Michael Filozof says he was fired from his job as a political science professor after he was harassed by a predominantly left-wing department. Monday morning he filed suit against MCC and now he wants a payback.
 "It was an American flag. I didn't think it was too controversial, but apparently at MCC it was." 
 Filozof says his colleagues at MCC attacked his political views. It came as quite a shock, considering many professors decorate their office doors with political messages. The difference between his and others, he says, is that he's conservative while the others are liberal. 
 "The faculty at many institutions are not balanced. They live in a bubble, they don't live in the real world, and they've got views out of the mainstream. If you bring mainstream views into academia, you get discriminated against." 
 Filozof's contract wasn't renewed at the beginning of this year. Now he's filed a lawsuit claiming he was fired because of his political views.
 His attorney Nelson Thomas says it amounts to a violation of constitutional rights. "Being a government-run institution, you have to respect your employees' First Amendment rights and that's what they didn't do here." 
 An MCC spokesperson tells News 8 they are aware of the lawsuit but it's their policy not to comment on pending litigation.
 Filozof is suing for lost pay, and the pain and suffering he says he endured. In the meantime, he's been teaching part time at other schools in Western New York but says he took a severe pay cut. He also says that he never brought his views into the classroom.
 "I never was accused by anyone, faculty or students, of being overly political, no." The lawsuit was filed Monday morning and MCC has 20 days to respond.
